question:
Background: Hexcel® HexWeb® ACG®-1/2 Honeycomb Aluminum Commercial Grade (discontinued) is produced using 3000 series aluminum alloy foil. This foil is coated with an organic layer offering superior protection against corrosive environments. The material is characterized by its cellular honeycomb structure, created by bonding sheets of aluminum foil and expanding them. The node bond adhesive, a thermosetting type, is cured under heat and pressure in the unexpanded state known as HOBE®. HexWeb® ACG® offers a range of cell sizes and densities, with sheet thicknesses available from 0.125 to 20 inches. Perforated aluminum substrates enable all cells in slices as thin as 0.187 inches to be vented, allowing outgassing of adhesives, though non-perforated options are also available. Applications for HexWeb® ACG® span across industrial tooling panels, architectural panels, shelving, storage tank covers, building walls, and tabletops, due to its long service life and resistance to fungus, moisture, and temperature. This material exhibits notable physical and mechanical properties, including a density of 0.0368 g/cc, a compressive yield strength of 1.31 MPa (bare) or 1.41 MPa (stabilized), a compressive modulus of 0.276 GPa, and shear strength ranging from 0.552 MPa to 0.965 MPa for plate shear in different directions.

Background: The Hexcel® HexWeb® CR III 3/8-5052-.003 is a corrosion-resistant specification grade aluminum honeycomb, designated as 'Cell Size-Alloy-Foil Gauge.' It's fabricated using aerospace-grade aluminum honeycomb materials, specifically 5052 and 5056 alloys, and is available in a variety of cell sizes and foil gauges. This material features the HexWeb® CR III coating, an organo-metallic polymer that provides superior protection against corrosion by forming a stable and tightly adherent bond with the aluminum surface. Manufactured by bonding sheets of aluminum foil and expanding them into a cellular honeycomb configuration, the material results in panels with clean, sharp cell walls that are burr-free, making them ideal for high-quality core-to-facing bonds. The aluminum HexWeb® CR III is primarily used in sandwich structures for highly engineered structural components across all types of aerospace vehicles and supporting equipment. These structures benefit from the material's rigid panels, minimal weight, aerodynamic smooth surfaces, and high fatigue resistance. Commercial applications include tools, snow and water skis, bulkheads, and floors, while nonstructural applications encompass directional air/fluid flow control, RF shielding, and energy absorption. Physically, the material has a nominal density of 0.0673 g/cc (0.00243 lb/in³). Mechanically, it exhibits compressive yield strengths of >= 2.31 MPa (>= 335 psi) bare minimum and >= 2.45 MPa (>= 355 psi) stabilized minimum, with typical values of 3.59 MPa (520 psi) bare and 3.86 MPa (560 psi) stabilized. The compressive modulus is 0.931 GPa (135 ksi) stabilized typical. In terms of shear modulus, it measures 0.200 GPa (29.0 ksi) plate shear in the W direction and 0.448 GPa (65.0 ksi) in the L direction, both typical. The shear strengths are >= 1.03 MPa (>= 150 psi) plate shear in the W direction, minimum, with typical values of 1.38 MPa (200 psi), and in the L direction >= 1.76 MPa (>= 255 psi), with typical values of 2.14 MPa (310 psi).

question:
Background: Hexcel® HexWeb® CR III 1/8-5056-.001 Corrosion Resistant Specification Grade Aluminum Honeycomb is an aerospace grade material made from 5052 and 5056 expanded aluminum. It features a HexWeb® CR III coating system that provides superior protection in corrosive environments by forming a stable, tightly adherent bond with the aluminum surface. This coating is an organo-metallic polymer that differs from conventional conversion-type protective coatings. The material is manufactured by bonding sheets of aluminum foil and expanding them into a cellular honeycomb configuration, leading to burr-free panels with sharp, clean cell walls. It has a density of 0.0721 g/cc (0.00260 lb/in³). In terms of mechanical properties, the compressive yield strength of the material is at least 3.28 MPa (475 psi) in bare form and 3.45 MPa (500 psi) when stabilized. The typical compressive yield strength reaches 4.34 MPa (630 psi) bare and 4.76 MPa (690 psi) when stabilized. The compressive modulus is 1.28 GPa (185 ksi), and the shear modulus is 0.193 GPa (28.0 ksi) in the W direction and 0.483 GPa (70.0 ksi) in the L direction, both measured in plate shear. Regarding its composition, Aluminum 6201-T6 consists mainly of Aluminum, Al (97.3 - 98.9 %), with additional elements including Magnesium, Mg (0.60 - 0.90 %), Silicon, Si (0.50 - 0.90 %), and trace amounts of Boron, B (<0.06 %), Chromium, Cr (<0.03 %), Copper, Cu (<0.10 %), Iron, Fe (<0.50 %), Manganese, Mn (<0.03 %), Zinc, Zn (<0.10 %), and other elements each making up less than 0.03 %, with a total of other elements not exceeding 0.10 %.

Background: The product name is Hexcel® HexWeb® CR III 3/16-5056-.002 Corrosion Resistant Specification Grade Aluminum Honeycomb. This material is noted to be of the specification grade, designated as Cell Size-Alloy-Foil Gauge. Made from 5052 and 5056 expanded aerospace grade aluminum, the honeycomb comes in a variety of cell sizes and foil gauges. The HexWeb® CR III coating provides superior corrosion protection, forming a stable, tightly adherent bond with the aluminum using an organo-metallic polymer. The honeycomb structure is created by bonding and expanding aluminum foil sheets, resulting in clean and burr-free cell walls suitable for high-quality core-to-facing bonds. It is predominantly used in sandwich structures for aerospace components due to its rigidity, minimal weight, aerodynamic surface, and high fatigue resistance. The material has a density of 0.0913 g/cc or 0.00330 lb/in³ nominal. Mechanically, its compressive yield strength ranges from a minimum of 4.72 MPa (685 psi) bare to a typical stabilized strength of 6.89 MPa (1000 psi). The compressive modulus is 1.86 GPa (270 ksi) stabilized, while the shear modulus varies between 0.248 GPa (36.0 ksi) in the W direction to 0.648 GPa (94.0 ksi) in the L direction. Shear strength ranges from a minimum of 1.93 MPa (280 psi) in the W direction to 3.90 MPa (565 psi) typically in the L direction. Besides aerospace, it finds use in commercial tools, skis, bulkheads, floors, and applications requiring air/fluid control, RF shielding, or energy absorption.

Its mechanical properties include a Brinell Hardness of 192, a Knoop Hardness of 214, Rockwell Hardness B of 91, Rockwell Hardness C of 11, and Vickers Hardness of 201. The ultimate tensile strength is 635 MPa (92100 psi), and the yield tensile strength is 400 MPa (58000 psi). It can elongate at break by 26.2% and has a reduction of area of 68.2%. The modulus of elasticity is 205 GPa (29700 ksi) and the bulk modulus is 160 GPa (23200 ksi). The shear modulus is 80.0 GPa (11600 ksi), and it has a Poisson's ratio of 0.29. It has a machinability rating of 65%. The material has a specific heat capacity of 0.475 J/g-°C (0.114 BTU/lb-°F) and a thermal conductivity of 44.5 W/m-K (309 BTU-in/hr-ft²-°F). The chemical composition includes Carbon (0.17-0.23%), Iron (97.995-98.88%), Manganese (0.35-0.75%), Molybdenum (0.45-0.60%), Phosphorus (≤ 0.035%), Silicon (0.15-0.35%), and Sulfur (≤ 0.040%).
